fact: Recycling one aluminum can saves enough energy to run a TV for three hours.
explanation: Recycling aluminum is highly efficient, using only about 5% of the energy needed to produce new aluminum from raw bauxite ore.
tip: Always recycle your aluminum cans. It's one of the most effective ways to save energy through recycling.

fact: A single mature tree can absorb up to 48 pounds of carbon dioxide per year.
explanation: Through photosynthesis, trees convert CO2 into oxygen and store the carbon in their wood, roots, and leaves, acting as natural carbon sinks.
tip: Plant a native tree in your yard or support reforestation projects to help combat climate change.

fact: The Great Pacific Garbage Patch is twice the size of Texas.
explanation: Ocean currents, called gyres, concentrate plastic waste into massive floating patches. The Great Pacific Garbage Patch is the largest of these.
tip: Reduce your use of single-use plastics and participate in local clean-up events to prevent plastic from reaching the ocean.

fact: Turning off the tap while brushing your teeth can save up to 8 gallons of water per day.
explanation: A standard faucet can flow at a rate of 2 gallons per minute. Leaving it running during a two-minute brush wastes a significant amount of water.
tip: Make it a habit to turn off the water while brushing your teeth and washing your hands.

fact: LED light bulbs use at least 75% less energy than incandescent bulbs.
explanation: LEDs are far more efficient at converting electricity into light, with less energy wasted as heat. They also last up to 25 times longer.
tip: Replace the most frequently used light bulbs in your home with energy-efficient LEDs to save electricity and money.

fact: Globally, we throw away about 1.3 billion tons of food every year.
explanation: Food waste occurs at every stage, from farm to fork. When food rots in a landfill, it produces methane, a potent greenhouse gas.
tip: Plan your meals, buy only what you need, and compost your food scraps to reduce food waste.

fact: Fast fashion is responsible for 10% of humanity's carbon emissions.
explanation: The production of clothing requires vast amounts of water, energy, and chemicals. The industry's rapid production cycle encourages overconsumption and waste.
tip: Choose quality over quantity. Buy second-hand, repair your clothes, and support sustainable fashion brands.

fact: A plant-based diet can reduce an individual's carbon footprint from food by up to 73%.
explanation: Livestock farming is a major source of greenhouse gases, land use, and water pollution. Growing plants is significantly more resource-efficient.
tip: Try incorporating more plant-based meals into your week. Even a 'Meatless Monday' can make a big difference.

fact: Bees are responsible for pollinating about one-third of the food we eat.
explanation: Many fruits, vegetables, and nuts rely on pollinators like bees to reproduce. A decline in bee populations threatens global food security.
tip: Plant a pollinator-friendly garden with native flowers and avoid using pesticides to help support local bee populations.

fact: About 8 million metric tons of plastic enter our oceans every year.
explanation: This plastic waste harms marine life through ingestion and entanglement, and it breaks down into microplastics that contaminate the entire food web.
tip: Carry a reusable water bottle and coffee cup. Refuse plastic straws and bags whenever possible.
